titleStmt.title: John Quincy Adams Diary Digital Project

div.p: 1. Bathed with George this morning, at the platform of the new Baptist Church— Remainder of the day principally at home—writing at my lecture, and reading— I looked into Court de Gebelin’s Origines du Langage—Gregory’s economy of Nature, and Rousseau’s Dictionaire de Musique with a view to get a more thorough knowledge of the internal organs of the voice, and the theory of sounds— But I could not get satisfaction— Evening walk with the Ladies in the Mall.

2. Bathed again this Morning, and took George with me, but he did not venture to go in— I was engaged the whole day upon my lecture which I find difficult to finish— And my progress though I lost no time was very slow. Walking in the Mall this Evening, I met Mr: De Grand who walk’d and came home with us— At home we found Mr: Everett; and these gentlemen pass’d a couple of hours with us.

3. Bathed this morning, at 6. with Mr: De Grand and George— We were rather too long, and late before we got home. Mr: De Grand swam too far, and could not get entirely back— He breakfasted with me— I accompanied the Select-men upon their annual visit to deer-island.— There were about eighty persons of company— Just before they landed I went with Dr: Welsh and some other Gentlemen, in two canoes, and fished untill dinner time— We caught about ten dozen perch and other small fish— We dined at the island, and returned to town, so as to land just at dusk— I went immediately to the Club at Judge Davis’s.— About half the Members were there— I had a long discussion upon political topics, principally with Judge Dawes, but in which all the others, excepting Kirkland and Spooner, occasionally took part against me— It was however good humoured.

4. Mr: Boylston called for me by appointment, shortly before eleven O’Clock this Morning, and I went with him out to Quincy, where we dined at my father’s— We returned this Evening, and I reached home just at dusk— Mr: De Grand came; and I went with him, and bathed— Taking George with us— Walk’d afterwards with the Ladies in the Mall— It was the warmest day we have had, this Summer.

div.p: 5. Walk’d to Cambridge this Morning, and at 10. O’Clock read my 35th: Lecture— There was less Company from abroad than usual.— But Mr: J. Gardner was there.— Dr: Townsend of Boston was also there— Mr: Gardner after the Lecture shewed me some Portsmouth Newspapers— I dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s, and at two attended the Declamation— The performances were as numerous and as good as those of the last week.— Walk’d home, and in the Evening with the Ladies in the Mall. We met Mr: Everett, who came home and sat half an hour with us. The weather in the course of this day has become very cool— I was fatigued with my walks and exercises, and only finished reading Swift’s early history of England.

6. Pass’d the forenoon chiefly at my Office; reading the life of Algernon Sidney, before a new edition of his book upon Government, lately published at New-York— I was half an hour at the Insurance Office— Evening walk with the Ladies in the Mall— Remainder of the day, writing at my last Lecture, which however I did not finish.

div.p: 7. Heard Mr: Emerson this morning, and Mr: Buckminster in the afternoon. The latter was so unwell, that he apologized for leaving his Sermon unfinished, and could scarcely get through the Services— I was employed the greatest part of the day, upon my lecture, which I finished, and with it my first course, upon Rhetoric— It is however very incomplete, and I hope, on going over it a second time, to make many additions and improvements upon it— I read also two Sermons of Massillon—and resumed the instruction of my Son George in the French Language— Mrs: Adams was somewhat unwell.

8. Mr: William White called upon me this morning, and engaged himself as a Student in my Office; where he also attended. I was there most of the forenoon, and purpose henceforth constantly to attend; and to devote to this profession all the time I can— I read there Sir William Jones’s preface to his translation of Isaeus, and the first of the Speeches— In the afternoon I began also to read Leland’s translation of Demosthenes— I intend in the morning to give some time to that Orator in his own Language.— Mr: De Grand was with us in the Evening, and we amused ourselves with Chess.

9. There was a town-meeting held this day, and a Petition to the President U.S. agreed upon, for the removal of the Embargo, at least so far as regards Spain and her Colonies; or for the immediate calling together of Congress— This meeting I did not attend— I was employed all the morning in reading Demosthenes—partly in Greek and partly in English— The afternoon I spent at my Office; and read a couple of Speeches of Isaeus— Received a letter from my brother in consequence of which I must send word to Mr: Boylston not to expect us to-morrow, but the next day.

10. My father and brother came into town this morning— I went with my father to Cambridge and attended the Meeting of the Academy.— We called first at Judge Dana’s house, but found he was gone to Newport— We next went to Mr: Gerry’s, and saw him; his Lady, and family— There was little business done at the Academy— We returned to Boston to dinner—& in the Evening my father returned home— Mr: J. Rutledge, who was passing by my house in a Carriage with Mrs: H. G. Otis saw my father sitting at the window, and called in to see him— In the Evening I attended the Club, at Judge Dawes’s.

11. Went out, with my wife, Catherine Johnson, and our children, George and Charles, and dined with Mr: Boylston, at Jamaica-Plains— My father & mother were there— My brother and his wife; and Louisa Smith—Chief-Justice Parsons—the President of the College, Webber, and Dr: Warren— Judge Parsons was in high Spirits, and full of conversation, upon a great variety of topics.— We returned home early this Evening— And walked afterwards in the Mall.

div.p:
12. Walk’d to Cambridge this morning; and at 10. O’Clock delivered my 36th: Lecture with which I conclude the course. Rode part of the way in a Chaise with Dr: Cheever— Dined at Dr: Waterhouse’s, where before dinner I met a Dr: Kollock of Savannah in Georgia— Attended the Declamation at 2. and returned immediately after to Boston— Walk’d with
the Ladies in the Evening, and paid a visit to Mr: and Mrs: W. Payne; but did not find them at home— Mr: Everett pass’d part of the Evening with us— I found myself very unwell.

13. I was quite ill the whole Night; and continued so the greatest part of this day— Unable to use any exertion or perform any labour; either of writing or reading— In the afternoon I was better, and went out to my father’s at Quincy, with Mr Loud, who came in for me with a Chaise— Took George out with me.

14. Heard Mr: Thacher of Dedham, both parts of the day— Mr: Quincy called at my father’s in the Evening— Though somewhat recovered I was still so unwell as not to have read any thing with much attention— I perused in a cursory manner however a part of Tyng’s Reports.

15. Another Night of watching; unable to get more than two hours of rest, this morning.— Returned to Boston with George, in the Stage— Mr: S. A. Otis and his family reached my fathers house this morning just before we left it— Attended the forenoon at my Office—and read Jones’s Isaeus.— Afternoon at home— So much wearied that I could not command my own attention— Read therefore in Retzs Memoirs— Evening walk with the Ladies—

16. Attended this forenoon at my Office— Afternoon at home; but instead of pursuing the proper course of my studies I got engaged in reading Retz’s Memoirs, and so interested in the Story, that I could not leave the book untill the darkness of Evening took it from my hands— Walk with Mrs: Adams— Catherine was at a party at Mr: Foster’s— Mr: De Grand spent the Evening and supp’d with us— The house in which he lodged was burnt the night before last, and he barely escaped with his life, with the loss of almost all his Effects— He was awaked by the smoke in his chamber, and had only time, without dressing himself to go down the Stair-case, and out of the house.

17. Forenoon at my Office, and afternoon at home, reading and writing— I cannot make that application to which my wishes and my duties prompt me, without producing an immediate aggravation of the complaint in my eyes— I read and analyzed the 5th: Speech of Isaeus, and the second Olynthiac of Demosthenes— Club this Evening at Dr: Dexter’s.

18. I propose henceforth a regular attendance at my Office in the forenoon, and to employ the other part of the day in my library at home— This afternoon my brother was here from Quincy— He had come in with his wife— Mine and Catherine Johnson pass’d the Evening at Miss Danforth’s— Our youngest child, Charles is this day a year old.

19. Annual visitation of the town schools, by the selectmen and School-Committee— I attended them at the two South Schools, and at the West-Boston Schools— After which I walk’d to Cambridge, and attended the declamation at 2— I returned afterwards with Dr: Waterhouse to Boston— He is going next week to New-York— I wrote for him a couple of letters of Introduction to Gentlemen there.— Remainder of the day reading Plutarch’s life of Demosthenes, in the old English Translation, and in a lesson of French, to George— In this undertaking to teach him I perceive the want of an art of teaching, in myself, more than the want of a facility to learn in him— It is also a severe trial of Patience and of Perseverance

20. Morning at my Office, and afternoon at home. Charles was very sick last Night, and has continued unwell this day. Evening’s walk in the Mall— My occupations are sufficient to employ all my time in a manner very agreeable to myself, but the weakness in my eyes is a great and increasing discouragement.

21. Heard Mr: Emerson, morning and afternoon— Mrs: A. went, part of the day; Catherine Johnson was very unwell the whole day— I read Tillotson’s Sermons 139 and 140— And employed the remaining leisure of the day in lessons of French & English reading to George.

22. I was engaged part of this afternoon, in looking over two of the performances for Commencement, and for the exhibition to-morrow— In the Evening I called and paid a visit to my neighbour Mr: Foster— The rest of the day was spent in regular study. At present I do not write so much as I ought.

23. I went with Mrs: Adams and Catherine to Cambridge, and attended the exhibition; which was good— The introductory Latin Oration by Hayward; the English Oration by Gray— A poem by Field— We returned to Boston to dinner— The afternoon I gave almost entirely to the instruction of George, whose mind is opening rapidly, and who become desirous of learning. In the Evening, walking in the Mall, we met Mr: De Grand, who came home and supp’d with us— Heard from Quincy, & from Mr: Peirce whom I saw at Cambridge, that my dear Mother was very sick.

24. Attended at my Office this morning, where I had various visitors, and read the less— At the insurance Office, where I saw Mr: T. Greenleaf and Mr: G. Apthorp; but neither of them had heard from my mother this day— Mr: W. Smith told me that Dr: Welsh had been confined to his house these ten days, by a breeding sore on his hand— I call’d there in the Evening to see him— He has been quite ill, but is recovering. Club at Dr: Elliot’s; which was well attended; and where besides our own members I found Dr Mason of New-York—Mr: Reid, my old College tutor; and Mr: Andrews of Newbury-Port.

25. Mr: Loud came in this morning from Quincy, intending to read Law in my Office, for a few Months— Mr: Everett has been gone all this week to Dartmouth College; to Commencement— I was at my Office all the morning; but was employed all the afternoon in teaching George— Evening walk in the Mall; but Mrs: A— being unwell was not with us.

26. My brother and his wife with their daughter Abigail came into town this Morning, and dined with us, as also did Mr: Loud. I finished this morning at my Office the perusal of Sir William Jones’s translation of Isaeus, upon which however I have some further remarks to make— But I lost my morning’s exercise upon the first Philippic, and the afternoon and Evening were devoted to my friends.

27. My father called at my house this morning, with Mr: Quincy, with whom he was going to dine at Mr: Lyman’s at Waltham, with the agricultural Society— This and some other transient avocations employed me at home the greatest part of the morning. I was however at my Office a couple of hours— In the afternoon I read one of the Philippics, and heard George in French— His progress is more rapid than mine— We went out with my father and Mr: Quincy, on their return from Waltham.

28. Heard Mr: Harris of Dorchester, both parts of the day, and during the remainder, was looking up books to assist me in my purposed examination of Demosthenes.— But meeting Professor Winthrop’s two Lectures upon Comets, and his account of his voyage to Newfoundland in 1761. to observe the transit of Venus, I employed a few hours in reading them— Among the branches of Science in which my ignorance is most inexcusable, I have long considered that of Astronomy— But I want Time, and I want helps— Particularly globes—and a Telescope.

29. Return’d with George this morning to Boston— Mr: T. Welsh’s boy soon after came and informed me that my tenant Dunwell the taylor had absconded and gone off— I went and found his shop emptied of every thing but a few old clothes, shreds and patches, which I suffered his brother to take away— He is gone largely in my debt— At my office, only a short time— I found there both Mr: Everett, and Mr: Loud— A Mr: Trevitt applied to me for a recommendation to the Secretary at War, for a commission in the medical department of the army— I gave him a letter accordingly— Spent the afternoon in teaching George, and analyzing the third Philippic— After our Evening’s walk I read a chapter in Adams’s astronomical essays—

30. Morning at my Office; continuing the analysis of Sir William Jones’s Commentary on Isaeus; afternoon employed in teaching George; and in reading the fourth Philippic.— Read something more of Adams’s astronomical Essays in the Evening. Meeting of the historical Society this afternoon

31. Commencement day— Mrs: Adams and Catherine, not choosing to go, I went alone. Walk’d over the Bridge; and there took a Chaise, to the Colleges— Called at Dr: Waterhouse’s, where I found Mr: Bradford of Roxbury. Thence I went to the Library; and accompanied the procession to the Meeting-House— The performances began late, and were not finished untill 4. O’Clock P.M— They were in general very indifferent— I dined in the Hall—called after dinner, at the chambers of Mr: Norton’s, and Mr: Codman’s sons; and return’d early in the Evening, home. On my way I was overtaken by a Carriage, with Mr: Jackson, Dr: Lathrop, Dr: Eliot, and Judge Davis, members of the Corporation, who gave me a seat with them— Henry Parkman called in the Evening to borrow a Seneca— I read further in the Astronomical Essays.

Day— I rise not very regularly, but usually between 5 and 7. Read four chapters in the Bible— Write my diary, for the preceding day— Translate with interlinear version a section of Demosthenes, by Mountenay— Breakfast— Am commonly detained at home an hour or two, by some visitor, or domestic avocation— At my Office from 11. untill 2— Reading Jones’s Isaeus— Come home to dinner— Afternoon employed, in reading and writing from Leland’s Demosthenes; and in teaching George to read in french— Untill dark— Walk half an hour in the mall.— Home and Sup about 10— Bed at 11.
